templateAssets.content: AP CREDIT: Prospective, transfer applicants who have completed a minimum of four major prep courses (all passed with letter grades) by the end of the fall semester are eligible to use Advanced Placement credit (scores of 4 or higher) in Statistics, Psychology and Microeconomics to satisfy the three remaining course requirements.

The Communication major provides students with comprehensive knowledge of the nature of human communication at multiple levels of analysis. The major coursework includes content from the natural and social sciences, as well as the humanities. Four areas of focus are offered: communication technology and digital systems, interpersonal communication, mass communication and media institution, and political and legal communication.


THIS MAJOR IS HIGHLY SELECTIVE and the demand for this major significantly exceeds space available. A minimum UC transferable GPA of 3.7 is required.


Listed below are the lower division preparation courses for the major. Students must complete a minimum of four major preparation courses from the seven listed by the end of fall term before transfer.

  • One course in introduction to mass and interpersonal communication (COMM 10: If two courses are listed on Assist as equivalents of Comm 10, then BOTH courses must be completed in order to satisfy this major requirement.)
  • One course in principles of public speaking
  • One course in introduction to linguistics, meaning of communication, or culture in communication
  • One statistics course
  • Three courses from:
  • Introductory Psychology
  • Introduction to American Government/Politics
  • Introductory to Sociology
  • Microeconomics or Introduction to Political Economy

All courses must be taken for a letter grade.


For more information regarding this major and UCLA's transfer selection process, visit https://comm.ucla.edu/ and https://admission.ucla.edu/


PLEASE NOTE: the community college courses listed below have been approved to satisfy the preparation requirements for this major at UCLA, but they may not be exact equivalents of the UCLA courses listed.

visibleCrossListedCourses.courseTitle: Statistics and Research Methods in Social Science
